description: From French niche, from Middle French niche, from Old French niche, from nicher (“to make a nest”) (modern French nicher), from Vulgar Latin *nīdicāre, from Latin nīdus (“nest”). Doublet of nidus and nide via Latin and nest via Proto-Indo-European; also related to nyas.

adjectives.description: niche (comparative more niche, superlative most niche)

entries.meaning: Pertaining to or intended for a market niche; having specific appeal.
(architecture) A cavity, hollow, or recess, generally within the thickness of a wall, for a statue, bust, or other erect ornament.
Any similar position, literal or figurative.
Specifically, a cremation niche; a columbarium.
(ecology) A function within an ecological system to which an organism is especially suited.
(by extension) Any position of opportunity for which one is well-suited, such as a particular market in business.
(Islam) An arrow woven into a prayer rug pointing in the direction of qibla.

verbs.description: niche (third-person singular simple present niches, present participle niching, simple past and past participle niched)

entries.meaning: (transitive, marketing) To specialize in a niche, or particular narrow section of the market.
examples: Product differentiation will be mostly limited to market niching and fashion.
